UN Women Turkey Country Office will hire a company to conduct the first comprehensive research on Violence against Women in Politics (VAWP) in Turkey.  Which will help in strengthening the evidence base on women’s political participation experiences and obstacles etc. A terms of reference had been developed in collaboration with HQ and ECA Regional Office. The bidding process has been initiated in the last quarter of 2021.
UN Women’s partnership with the Foundation for Solidarity with Women - KADAV, KAMER Foundation, Flying Broom Foundation, and the Turkish Women's Union Association will lead to the establishment and operationalization of a first step station for survivors of violence in Istanbul in collaboration with a municipality, development of advocacy and knowledge products targeting diverse stakeholders, as well as research and monitoring reports on fields where data gaps persist, among others.

Women acted in solidarity against common problems such as GBV and COVID-19 pandemic through solidary groups and women committees which also contributed to strengthening the social cohesion at the local level.

2023 Narrative: (UNW) 668 women and girls, including 128 rural, 114 from minority groups, 119 aged ≤18, and 27 refugees have been equipped with necessary financial knowledge and management skills, being supported in their journey toward financial independence and resilience. Out of them:•      Approximately 200 women have increased their confidence in financial matters, understanding economics and money management, financial goals and life planning, banking instruments, credit management, investments and many other topics during a comprehensive one-month-long training marathon “Bani la feminin’’, consisting of both online and offline components, complemented by individual and group study. This activity represented a transformative initiative focused on empowering women in their financial journey.•      A dedicated session was organized specifically to Ukrainian women refugees. The session attracted approximately 27 participants. The positive response and active participation in this specialized session underscore our commitment to inclusivity, recognizing and addressing the diverse financial needs of women in refugee circumstances.•      110 teenagers foster financial skills and independence by participating at financial education camps in Bălți and Comrat. The camps not only provided financial knowledge but also included visits to financial institutions, museums, and unique experiences like Crunchyroll, offering valuable insights into financial concepts. These endeavors extended beyond physical camps to an online financial education course tailored for parents (60 parents) who acquired necessary skills in discussing money matters with their children.•      200 teachers across the country learned about concepts related to financial literacy during a two-day training session and 21 kindergarten educators from four institutions have learnt how to teach financial literacy concepts to preschoolers effectively. Participants have been engaged in discussions acknowledging the necessity of cultivating responsible behavior in managing personal budgets. 42 women refugees integrated in the labor market or any income-generating activity through the Cash for Work program (employment, internship, professional courses, registration of business, purchase of equipment, extension of business, social assistance and support of Moldovan entrepreneurs in recruitment of Ukrainian women refugees), offering them up to 10 000 MDL to enter the labor market. 35 women advanced in career while harmonizing their personal and professional lives through the voucher for children programme. 2023 Narrative: In partnership with the Ministry of Education (MOE) UNICEF continued to strengthen peer violence prevention mechanisms and stress resilience for children and pedagogues.Recognizing prevention of bullying as critical for children, the MOE with UNICEF continued to roll-out the Safe and Enabling Environment in Schools (SEES) programme, with a 39% increase in participating schools. With 43 pilot schools SEES is now present in all the regions, with additional attention paid to the regions with higher numbers of refugee children from Ukraine to strengthen protective environments. Focus group discussions among 121 adolescents representing 7 pilot schools have revealed that the majority of children know what is bullying, how to identify it, how to react and the importance of action from those who witness it. Focus groups served as a mid-term assessment on the model’s efficiency and perceptions by children and pedagogues. UNICEF developed a dedicated page on the U-Platform to consolidate key SEES resources informing children and teachers about pilot results, enhancing access to anti-bullying and mental health resources, and enabling children and pedagogues to share information and data on SEES activities.In 2023, a key SESS focus was on advancing participatory processes with adolescents co-creating anti-bullying solutions. UNICEF empowered 30 young people (20 female, 10 male) to practice their communications skills and spread the ideas of the SEES project in their schools, through peer-support groups, discussions with younger children on bullying prevention, art projects, and other initiatives. Applying the UPSHIFT methodology, sixty adolescents (52 girls and 8 boys), including five adolescents with disabilities, created social projects such as antibullying comics; a workbook for children and adolescents who use violence against their peers; and a board game “Smash bullying”.Advancement of SEES values and practices among parents and communities played a vital role in increasing the sustainability of peer-violence prevention interventions and promoted a violence-free environment not only in schools but throughout communities. Through a streamed online marathon, adolescents presented the results of their anti-bullying initiatives to peers, teachers, and parents from more than 30 schools across Belarus, reaching over 3,000 views and at least 6,000 peers, teachers and parents. Use of traditional and social media publications resulted in more than 32,000 views. As a result of the community engagement, 10 new schools joined SEES project and dozens more expressed interest.UNICEF also supported the Belarusian State Pedagogical University in piloting the psycho-social support programme, “Safe Spaces” in school settings. The model contains basic psycho-social responses to help children cope with stresses and was officially certified by the National Institute of Education. Starting from the 2023/2024 academic year, the model has been piloted in 20 Belarusian schools.
